thread.title: Beston joins Port Lincoln tuna barons in drive to supply Shanghai sushi bars
thread.title_full: Beston joins Port Lincoln tuna barons in drive to supply Shanghai sushi bars

author: Simon Evans
title: Beston joins Port Lincoln tuna barons in drive to supply Shanghai sushi bars
text:
The proliferation of sushi and sashimi bars in Shanghai and Beijing is proof of the long-term growth prospects of the premium tuna industry says Beston Global Food chairman Roger Sexton, whose company is funding the acquisition of Mori Seafood based in Port Lincoln, the town that had the most millionaires per capita of any location in Australia in the early 2000s because of tuna fishing.
It's a roller-coaster industry that built the fortunes of Tony Santic – who went on to achieve national fame as the owner of racehorse Makybe Diva, the three-time Melbourne Cup winner – and fellow tuna baron Hagen Stehr, who had net wealth estimated by the BRW Rich 200 of $270 million in the late 2000s. Mr Stehr is still a major shareholder in Clean Seas Tuna, a company that is symbolic of the volatility in the industry, with a share price now languishing at 6¢ after being at $1.30 in early 2008.
Dr Sexton has built up an array of premium food assets across dairy, lobsters, meat and health nutrition under the Beston Global Food banner, which is raising up to $130 million in an initial public offering before listing on the ASX next month, and will use some of the proceeds for the acquisition of Mori Seafood, founded in 1989 by the Moriarty family.
Dr Sexton – who is also the chairman of IOOF Holdings, the under-fire financial services company that has been in the spotlight over serious allegations of misconduct by some staff which resulting in its chief executive Chris Kelaher being grilled by a Senate committee earlier this month – said there is high demand for premium seafood in Asia.
Mori Seafood processes about 600 tonnes of tuna each year under the MORITUNA label, with the vacuum-packed southern bluefin tuna mainly sold to high-end restaurants in the northern hemisphere. The entity being used to purchase Mori is lobster company Ferguson Australia, of which Beston Global Food owns 36 per cent.
Chinese tastes becoming more Japanese Dr Sexton said the changing tastes of consumers in China are telling: "as incomes rise, the tastes of people in China are moving more towards those of Japan," he said on Monday.
"You can see it Shanghai and Beijing – the sushi and sashimi bars are everywhere". The long-term fundamentals make it an attractive business even though there is volatility.
Mori Seafood also exports about 50 tonnes of live lobsters to China each year.
Japan, China and Hong Kong are the three main export markets for Australia's fish and seafood industry and make up about 70 per cent of total exports. Lobsters make up about 45 per cent of total exports from Australia, with tuna at 10 per cent and abalone at 13 per cent.
Beston will spend $5.4 million of the float proceeds to fund the purchase of Mori Seafood and a Five-Star Seafoods lobster quota, and has also earmarked $19.2 million to acquire the Pedra Branca dairy farm near Mount Gambier, and $12 million to acquire a 20 per cent stake in hi-tech food nutrition company Neptune Bio-Innovations. It also owns a stake in premium milk and yoghurt group B.-d. Farm Paris Creek.
Port Lincoln outstripped even the affluent eastern suburbs of Sydney such as Bellevue Hill and Double Bay and the blue-chip Melbourne suburb of Toorak in winning the crown of most millionaires per capita in 2003.
